Welcome back! This is a beginner‚Äôs course in Python and Part 2 in a series. If you missed Part 1, check it out here.

Ever needed a random playing card but didn‚Äôt have a deck nearby? Me neither! However, there have been apps popping up with games or workout routines that are based on random card generators, so why not replicate one?

In order to do this, we will be learning the following:

First thing‚Äôs first, head on over to Programmiz so you have your own environment to work in.

Take a look at this code. Let‚Äôs start at the bottom, with the statement: In Python terms, it means ‚Äúif I start the program in this file, run this code.‚Äù This is important because it helps us organize our code. And for clarity, answers ‚Äúare these equal?‚Äù with True/False, which is what statements need.

Now let‚Äôs talk about the statement itself, which is a conditional statement or a piece of logic that determines whether or not to execute some logic. We will talk more about statements a bit later but it‚Äôs important to note that all logic you want within the statement has to be indented, or have 4 spaces from the beginning of the if statement. Underneath that statement is , the function we see declared just above. Main is universal for ‚Äústart here‚Äù and it will be where we execute most of our other functions and logic.

Just above the function are our constants, or variables that won‚Äôt change throughout the program and are used primarily for reference. Variables are primarily split into 3 different types: local, class, and global. Local variables are accessed within functions and can‚Äôt be used outside those functions, class variables are declared within classes (ignore for now), and global variables can be referenced anywhere in the file. Local and class variables are always lowercase, with underscores used to separate the words used to describe them, and global variables or constants are always uppercase. There‚Äôs a long winded reason why constants are best practice involving run times and reusability outside our current file BUT we will leave that for another article.

As you can see, we have a constant for the suits of playing cards, and we have a constant for the ranks of the playing cards. Notice the brackets surrounding the strings? This indicates that the data type is a list. All of the comma separated strings within are the contents of the lists. Three important facts to note about lists in Python: len(list) returns the size of the list, the index for the first item in a list is 0, and python doesn‚Äôt care if the list contains different data types. If I wanted to print the ‚ÄúDiamonds‚Äù suite from , I would execute . Remove the double quotes around one of the numbers in . If you run the code, it won‚Äôt throw an error. Plus, since we are only printing out the values, we won‚Äôt have any code that expects a certain data type. Best Practice: Don‚Äôt mix data types in collections like lists. Just because we can doesn‚Äôt mean we should.

Now, in order to get a random suite and rank, we just need to again, get one value from each constant, and print both to the console. Easy peasy!

Fortunately, Python has made this incredibly easy for us, as has a function made just for container data types like our lists: . Write the code below and hit run!

The code prints out two items, the suite and the rank, but that‚Äôs not how we read playing cards! Let‚Äôs combine our variables into one easy to read sentence using string formatting.

There are many ways to format strings to create what we want but I‚Äôm going to use my favorite: f-strings. Normal strings are indicated by placing double quotes around the text, like the contents of our SUITS and RANKS lists. However, if we place an before the string, we indicate we want it to be a formatted string, which allows us to insert variables and logic within the string. Let‚Äôs see it in action:

By wrapping our variables in , we can tell the formatter to execute the logic within, like getting the value of a variable. Now when we click run, the program will print out a random card in a human readable format, check it out! Side note: any valid logic can be run in , so the statement could have looked like and would have been executed just the same. However, using functions as arguments for other functions or in formatting can hurt the readability of the code. Personal Best Practice: Readability is King.

What? You want to play Poker with this? Because the cards outputted are too random, duplicate cards will appear where there shouldn‚Äôt be. In order to play any card game, we need a full deck to draw from. If I were to build a poker card drawing program it would look like this:

Instead of a list, I use a set collection for easy drawing using and use ‚Äúlist comprehension‚Äù to quickly construct the deck. After that, it‚Äôs just a matter of seeing how many players want to play poker and drawing their cards using a loop. The only problem? All the players would see each other‚Äôs cards!

A number of problems, so I suggest the real fix would be to throw this away and start over.

First thing to do: strings are for people, not computers, so don't represent cards as strings until you have to print something. Everywhere else, they should be numbers. Either a single number for each card, or a "card" object with numbers for rank and suit. Both player hands and decks are then just simple arrays (or in Python, lists).

Create a single global "deck" list from which to deal all the cards, initialize it with one of each, then deal to the player hands. There are two ways to deal random cards from a deck--your method is neither of them. Either (1) "shuffle" the deck using an algorithm called Fisher-Yates (Python's does this) and pop cards off the end of the deck array as you append them to hand arrays, or (2) To deal each card, select a card randomly from the remaining cards deck, append it to the hand, and remove it from the deck. This is also easy in Python with and .

A minor pythonism: don't use "str" as a variable name, it's already a built-in type.

A memory game is a type of game that can be used to test or check the memory of a human being. It is a very famous game. In this game, the player has some cards in front of him and all of them facing down initially. The player has to choose a pair of cards at one time and check whether the faces of both cards are matching or not. If the faces of both cards are the same, then the player can keep those cards face up and continue. Otherwise, the player needs to put the picked cards back face down and continue by selecting other cards. As a full-stack developer, one of the best ways to sharpen your front-end development skills is by building interactive projects with JavaScript. Implementing common UI patterns like games provides an opportunity to practice key programming concepts in a fun, engaging way.

In this article, we‚Äòll walk through the process of building a card matching game using vanilla JavaScript, HTML, and CSS. Along the way, you‚Äòll level up your JS abilities in areas like:

But the learning doesn‚Äòt stop there! Styling the game will flex your CSS muscles as you dive into responsive layouts with Grid and Flexbox, CSS animations and transitions, and more.

By the end, you‚Äòll not only have a fully functional game to play or add to your portfolio, but you‚Äòll also walk away with a handful of transferable, real-world programming techniques you can apply to any front-end development project. Let‚Äòs get started!

Before diving into the code, let‚Äòs make sure you have the tools needed.
‚Ä¢ Code Editor ‚Äì Any text editor will work, but I highly recommend using Visual Studio Code. It‚Äòs free, runs everywhere, and has a massive extensions library to supercharge your coding. I use it for all my web development.
‚Ä¢ Local Server ‚Äì To properly load assets and test features like local storage, you‚Äòll need to run the project on a web server instead of opening the files directly in your browser. If you‚Äòre using VS Code, the Live Server extension makes this a breeze. It starts up a development server and automatically reloads the page whenever you save changes.
‚Ä¢ Starter Files ‚Äì Create a new folder for the project with three files:

With that, you‚Äòre ready to start building! I encourage you to follow along and type out the code samples to get hands-on practice. If you get stuck, you can always refer to the [complete source code]().

Each card will need to display an icon or image and maybe some text. We‚Äòll also use data attributes to track its state (face-up or face-down) and its matched pair.

With the HTML skeleton in place, let‚Äòs turn our attention to the JavaScript needed to power the game engine. We‚Äòll use an object to track the game state:

The array will hold objects representing each card and its state. We‚Äòll populate this when starting a new game based on the chosen difficulty level.

To kick things off, let‚Äòs flesh out the function attached to the "New Game" button click:

This prompts the player to choose a deck size, generates an array of unique cards and their duplicates, shuffles them, and renders the cards to the page. It also kicks off a timer to track how long the game takes.

The meat of the gameplay happens in the event listener callback:

When a card is clicked, it‚Äòs flipped over (if valid) and added to the array. If two cards are flipped, the move count is incremented and we check for a match.

For matches, both cards are marked as "matched" and a check is done to see if the game has been won (all cards matched). For mismatches, the cards are flipped face-down again after a slight delay.

The helper function can flip a card in either direction based on an optional second argument:

Now for the fun part ‚Äì making the game look great! In styles.css, we can set up some basic styles for the page layout and the cards themselves.

With the core game complete, it‚Äòs time to think about some extra features and enhancements:
‚Ä¢ Difficulty levels ‚Äì Add buttons to choose between easy, medium, and hard difficulties. The harder the mode, the more cards to match.

Hi folks! I want to show you a game I made with React. It‚Äôs a popular russian card-game - Fool (or Durak). I created this project for fun and some practice with React and CSS. You can see the source code and result here.

And also I want to tell you how I organized a game logic and which design patterns I used in this.

In this game, the game process can be divided into several basic steps.
‚Ä¢ take cards if you cannot beat
‚Ä¢ remove cards from the table if the attack is over

As you can see, each of these steps is an action - ‚Äòto deal...‚Äô, ‚Äòto choose...‚Äô, ‚Äòto discard...‚Äô And these actions are ordered. And the game process dependents on the result of this actions. Also some actions have options (for example, ‚Äòdiscard a card‚Äô).

This pattern is ideal in this case. With this pattern we implement the logic of the actions in different classes, instead of different functions as usual. These classes will share the same "public" interface. As usually it is the ‚Äòapply‚Äô (or ‚Äòexecute‚Äô) method, which returns a result of the command.

Our next step will be creating instances of these command. Then we will call the apply method, which calls the ‚ÄòsetByTrump‚Äô –∏ ‚ÄòmoveCardsToPlayer‚Äô, which contain all main logic for our commands.

This is one of my favorite pattern)

I used a queue (FIFO) as the command container. When a new command is added, a new queue node is created and a link to that node is stored in the current last node. Then at the beginning of each frame we check if there are any commands in the queue. If there are, we apply the first command. If its result has completed status, then this command will be removed.

This pattern is excellent for actions like ‚Äòdiscard a card‚Äô, when behavior depends on some factor. In our case the factor is the player.

If the current player is an attacker, we need to check if there are open cards on the table and the like.

If the current player is a defender, the result of the command will depend on the rank of the card.
